- Offline cache - punted to follow on work
- Integrity checks - left as follow on work via `policies`
- CORS - not supported
- CA - TBD follow on work
- Cookies - TBD follow on work
- MIME parsing - wontfix / still broken since we don't have a real parser in core, I'm not gonna try to get `mime` landed anytime soon due to pushbacks

##### Documentation

##### Checklist
<!-- Remove items that do not apply. For completed items, change [ ] to [x]. -->

- [x] `make -j4 test` (UNIX), or `vcbuild test` (Windows) passes
- [x] tests and/or benchmarks are included
- [x] documentation is changed or added
- [ ] commit message follows [commit guidelines](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/doc/guides/contributing/pull-requests.md#commit-message-guidelines)

issue.title: Implement an Activity Policy
issue.body:
I'd like to recommend that we introduce an Activity Policy for organization membership to reduce the manual workload of maintaining organization membership and attempt to reduce the surface area for potential issues caused by escalated privileges.

I think we can probably be _incredibly_ lenient in what we consider "activity". I'd consider the following "activity", both in the nodejs and pkgjs orgs:
- Creating an Issue, PR, or Discussion (ex. `org:nodejs author:bnb created:>2021-01-01`)
- Commenting on an Issue, PR, or Discussion (ex. `org:nodejs commenter:bnb created:>2021-01-01`)
- Reviewing a PR (ex `org:nodejs reviewed-by:bnb created:>2021-01-01`)

I would also include "reacting to an Issue, PR, or Discussion" but it doesn't seem like GitHub has an API that would surface that information. If people think of more things to check programmatically that could be added, I'm wholly onboard with that. I believe our goal should be to consume _as many_ signals as possible, and given that we've consistently decided to centralize on GitHub I think using every available signal is a reasonable way to parse "has this person engaged with the project".

In terms of "what is the scope and approach":
- I'd recommend checking for checking the past year. I don't know of a point in history where an "active" member of the project didn't engage in some way in GitHub at one point or another within the previous 365 days. 
  - I'd recommend this be instant rather than moving to a temporary hold group before being released. In CommComm I pretty consistently noticed a pattern where when asked people would say yes but not return, creating an artificial inflation of the number of members despite a majority being in this limbo state.
- I'd recommend committing "decisions" in a repo, so we have an easy log that we can audit.
  - This could include a snapshot of their membership, allowing us to easily reinstate that.
- I'd recommend that we take a similar approach to how some groups have implemented Emeritus, where a simple request to be re-added (perhaps after some period of renewed activity, like a week or a month?) is all that's required. Perhaps this could also be automatic.

Would love to hear thoughts on this.

comment.body: Agree that it should be automated and via PR. If we've already got existing infrastructure in Actions, I think it makes sense to re-use that infrastructure.

review.body: +1. Also agree with the eventual goal of eslint recommended and happy to see work to get us closer to that :)

issue.title: doc: add styleguide

labels.name: doc
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the documentations.

issue.body:
This PR adds a documentation style guide. This comes as a result of https://github.com/nodejs/node/discussions/40953 and the various next-10 discussions that led to it. It is _largely_ a copy/paste from electron/electron's [styleguide.md](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/main/docs/styleguide.md), with some changes.

The goal of this is not to have it as an immediately enforceable, but rather to have it be planted as the guide that we'll eventually fully enforce on all documentation that it can be enforced on (some documentation, like native APIs, it can only be partially enforced on).

Landing this and, eventually, having all of our documentation written in this style should allows us the ability to use [docs-parser](https://github.com/electron/docs-parser) which produces a high-quality JSON output of markdown documentation written as the style guide defines. This would allow the DefinitelyTyped people to produce higher quality type definitions, potentially even just using Electron's [typescript-definitions](https://github.com/electron/typescript-definitions) tooling that parses docs-parser output into `.d.ts` files.

There are other, less objective benefits:
- highly consistent authoring experience that provides a consistent framework for writing and reviewing documentation
- more digestible documentation for end-users, structuring all documentation in a hierarchy that's consistent across pages while still being specific enough to provide meaningful context regardless of content

Worth noting, I also created https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/32206 some time ago, and this is one step towards that as a reality. In doing so, I also created [bnb/node-docs-parser](https://github.com/bnb/node-docs-parser) which snapshotted a few examples from the Node.js documentation at the time I created it and provided an example of what those documents would look like if they were migrated. While it's been a pandemic worth of time since I last worked on that repo and some of the docs have been updated (querystring in particular is much more consistent!), the documents in `/docs/api` are still pretty close to what the "translated" versions would look like if you want a reference.

changes to the styleguide.md from the e/e version include:

- updating the name (`Electron` > `Node.js`)
- removing references to `markdownlint`
  - given that Electron and docs-parser use markdownlint, it might make sense to migrate to it.
- removed a TODO above the linter rules, noting that they should be checked against what the electron/electron markdown parser checks for.
  - potentially worth investigating finding a middle ground and both using one set of tooling.
- tweaked examples to fit Node.js. As we build out the documentation to fit this style guide, we should update these examples to me more thorough.
- removed one example under the "function signature" heading on line 169, as I'm not immediately familiar of a class that has the same name as its module and can be used as an example. Happy to re-add this when I find a good example.
  - here's the original text, for reference: 
    - > For example, the methods of the `Session` class under the `session` module must use `ses` as the `objectName`.
- removed a reference on line 181 to Electron's cookie API custom sturcutre. Happy to re-add this back in once we've got our own custom structures added.
- added backticks to line 228 where they weren't in the Electron documentation. I believe the backticks are allowed/required, but should double check just to make sure that's a correct assertion before merging.

a few things to discuss:
- js code linting
  - Electron's standardized on StandardJS and has proper tooling for it, including [standard-markdown](https://www.npmjs.com/package/standard-markdown). While I'm personally fine with this, I assume the Node.js project would want a different linter solution documented.
  - happy to change the text on lines 55-56 referencing this if we don't want to keep this.
- I'm not sure if we have platform-specific functionality. If we don't and never plan on doing so, happy to remove line 194-203.
- how we want to approach inline YAML changelogs. Particularly, it was raised that it would be nice to have in Markdown but it may also become burdensome for those who backport, which is definitely not something I'd want to see.
  - potential solution here is to document an additional markdown structure for changelogs and then have a small tool convert YAML into that Markdown structure as a build step.
  - I'm unopinionated on what a solution is here, but ideally, we will *eventually* not have any YAML frontmatter.

and just for context, the ideal next steps _after_ this PR lands would be to begin incrementally migrating documentation to fit the style guide.

comment.body:
Going through all the comments since I've caught up on everything else I have to do:

> This feels like a very big change, essentially a rewrite/reformatting of all of Nodes documentation. While making the docs more parseable for type definitions is a worthy goal, Im not sure that the level of effort required here justifies that payoff.

@GeoffreyBooth it is effectively a _reformatting_ of all of our documentation. This doesn't particularly change the contents, unless you consider subsequent incremental changes to improve accuracy as a "change". If the TSC thinks that it's too much work, that's fine. I personally think it's worth it for the reasons that are outlined (there's more than just "making an API that improves types generation"!). 

> We should not have two duplicative style guides and we should certainly not have two contradictory style guides.

@Trott I agree! My apologies, I'll be honest I didn't realize there was a styleguide before I PR'ed this.

> Not sure if it isn't sufficiently high-quality, but there is already JSON-formatted documentation

Yeah, this came up in the prior discussions. If we _do_ have real-world users of this (I can think of a couple, for example Dash and the DefinitelyTyped people themselves), I think we should try to improve it. The difference isn't world-changing - much of the data is there, but it's more easily machine parsable which would theoretically help enhance the experience. You can see a good example of this in https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/32206. 

> I could be wrong about the extent of this, but there seems to be a desire for more JSDoc (to assist with IDEs, for example) so it might be worth bringing that into the discussion too. @aduh95

I'm curious what the IDE integration desires are here around JSDoc. Would love to know more.

>> Im also a big fan of the policy that we just follow the Microsoft Style Guide and thats it, and we spare ourselves debates over style questions. Adopting our own styleguide would seem to invite such debates.
> 
> Agreed, I don't think the Microsoft style guide touches on what is needed to make the docs parseble and we should not wander into that territory.

The one caveat I have here is that there might be reliance on the defined writing style in docs-parser (for example, looking for certain styles of heading). If folks could be specific with what they're referring to in this PR that replaces that, I'd be happy to dig deeper.

> > This feels like a very big change, essentially a rewrite/reformatting of all of Nodes documentation. While making the docs more parseable for type definitions is a worthy goal, Im not sure that the level of effort required here justifies that payoff.
>
> It is more of a tweak in many cases than re-write. The technical content should stay the same, the major changes would be how headings are used and formatting of parameters. @bnb can you link the sample of the before/after for the one you modified as I think it is a good example of how similar they feel

It's linked in the body of the PR, with the appropriate context. `bnb/node-docs-parser`.

> I'm trying to get docs-parser to work minimally with our docs.

@Trott you should look at the repo I linked in the body of the project. I've already done a lot of this work and outlined the challenges that you seem to be surprised by here in the original body of the PR.

RE: applying this to the existing style guide: I'm happy to do this, but I'd like confirmation that this is what we'd consider as a path to move forward. I'd rather not have to keep an independent file and the existing style guide in sync. If @trott and/or @mhdawson could confirm that's the best path forward, I'll start working on it

issue.title: Archive all old i18n repos and teams
issue.body:
We have quite a few old localization repos that, quite frankly, we've not maintained a strong relationship with. They've come up in organization management conversations over the past ~5 years, and generally we've just chosen to let them sit. If there's not currently a meaningful process that includes these repos, I'd rather not provide misdirection for people who might actually be interested in helping with i18n.

I'd like to propose that we begin to archive them, since it seems relatively clear to me that this approach to i18n isn't something we're committed to. If there _are_ folks who are still contributing to them (the only one I can find is the, the nodejs-ko repo, acting completely independently on its own GitHub Pages site, occasionally publishing [translated versions](https://nodejs.github.io/nodejs-ko/articles/2021/10/12/release-v12.22.7/) of official blog posts, cc @taggon, @yous), I'd like to see what we can to bring that in line with our current process for @nodejs/website rather than splitting it across tooling and domains.

I do think it might be time to ask for fiscal support from the Foundation to get a meaningful website redesign shipped. The scope of that work could/should absolutely include the foundations for strong i18n. I think that's likely a separate discussion, though.

comment.body:
I mean, it looks like https://github.com/nodejs/nodejs-vi/issues/23 was opened in 2018 and hasn't gotten any kind of response. Feels like a pretty strong indicator that it's not active and is not going to be active.

> I'd propose having some kind of positive recommendation, such as, "lets get this group going again!" and if there's not a response then archive.

I think this is fair, although I don't actually know what "activity" would look like for these groups since fundamentally how they were _initially_ structured around the iojs.org website is not a system that's supported anymore.

I think one approach might be "hey we'd really love to do i18n stuff with you! since this repo was last active, we've moved over to nodejs/i18n. we'd really love to work with you there." in any repo that's not had activity in the past... i dunno, 6 months?

In terms of "what is the scope and approach":

pull_request.title: fs: use async directory processing in cp()
pull_request.body:
The `readdir()` functions do not scale well, which is why `opendir()`, etc. were introduced. This is exacerbated in the current `cp()` implementation, which calls `readdir()` recursively.

This commit updates `cp()` to use the `opendir()` style iteration.

The `readdir()` functions do not scale well, which is why `opendir()`, etc. were introduced. This is exacerbated in the current `cp()` implementation, which calls `readdir()` recursively.

This commit updates `cp()` to use the `opendir()` style iteration.

comment.body: Would love to see perf metrics on this if you've got any handy

issue.title: Archive all old i18n repos and teams
issue.body:
We have quite a few old localization repos that, quite frankly, we've not maintained a strong relationship with. They've come up in organization management conversations over the past ~5 years, and generally we've just chosen to let them sit. If there's not currently a meaningful process that includes these repos, I'd rather not provide misdirection for people who might actually be interested in helping with i18n.

I'd like to propose that we begin to archive them, since it seems relatively clear to me that this approach to i18n isn't something we're committed to. If there _are_ folks who are still contributing to them (the only one I can find is the, the nodejs-ko repo, acting completely independently on its own GitHub Pages site, occasionally publishing [translated versions](https://nodejs.github.io/nodejs-ko/articles/2021/10/12/release-v12.22.7/) of official blog posts, cc @taggon, @yous), I'd like to see what we can to bring that in line with our current process for @nodejs/website rather than splitting it across tooling and domains.

I do think it might be time to ask for fiscal support from the Foundation to get a meaningful website redesign shipped. The scope of that work could/should absolutely include the foundations for strong i18n. I think that's likely a separate discussion, though.

Would it be possible for someone to install https://slack.github.com/ for nodejs/node, so that folks using the GitHub app in Slack can subscribe to releases etc. there?

issue.title: Add command to move directory to gh-pages branch

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: a request to improve CLI

labels.name: needs-triage
labels.description: needs to be reviewed

issue.body:
### Describe the feature or problem youd like to solve

For the past ~decade it's been a relative pain to have a static site that's compiled to a dist folder and host that on GitHub. Specifically, if you have an output folder at `/dist`, you then have to figure out how to get the contents of that folder into the gh-pages branch. This is a frustratingly high barrier that doesn't need to exist. I'd _really_ love to see some enhancements to the Pages configuration (for example, just let me choose any folder rather than _just_ the root or `/docs`), but having the CLI move contents of an output directory to a branch for this could still be complimentary to that if it were to eventually happen. Iterative improvements!

### Proposed solution

At the core, I just want something in `gh` that allows me to move content from an output directory to a target branch. This could be a one time thing or something I configure for a repo and then can run a command on-demand. Heck, going above and beyond I perhaps shouldn't even need to provide a target branch since `gh` could theoretically pull the name of the target branch from the API.

Most basic:
```sh
gh pages move <output directory> <target branch>
gh pages move ./dist gh-pages
gh pages move ./dist ILikeWeirdBranchNamesThatArentDescriptive
gh pages move $HOME/GitHub/org/repo/dist gh-pages
```

Configuration + move command:
```sh
# configure first...
gh pages configure source <output directory> <target branch>
gh pages configure source ./dist gh-pages
gh pages configure source ./dist ILikeWeirdBranchNamesThatArentDescriptive
gh pages configure source $HOME/GitHub/org/repo/dist gh-pages

# ... then move
gh pages move
```

Lower configuration because you can call the API + move command:
```sh
# configure first...
gh pages configure source <output directory>
gh pages configure source ./dist
gh pages configure source ./dist 
gh pages configure source $HOME/GitHub/org/repo/dist

# ... then move
gh pages move
```
### Additional context

The usage of the `gh-pages` branch and moving contents into it has been something that's been a problem that's been papered over for some number of years. For example, the `gh-pages` module [on npm](https://www.npmjs.com/package/gh-pages/v/0.1.0) - which in my experience is the de-facto way to manage this in a way that isn't infuriating - was originally published 8 years ago.  There's a massive legacy of content around this, all of which either has custom tooling (see, for example, Octopress's [article from 2011](http://octopress.org/docs/deploying/github/) on deploying to pages) that hides the pain or points people to the more raw, rather wonky ways you'd be able to migrate files from your default branch to the GitHub Pages branch (see, for example, this [blog post](https://jiafulow.github.io/blog/2020/07/09/create-gh-pages-branch-in-existing-repo/) by Jia Fu Low, a postdoctoral student at the University of Florida who's working on the Compact Muon Solenoid Phase 2 endcap muon trigger upgrade project at CERN's Large Hadron Collider).

comment.body:
> Fixing this is the main priority the Pages team is working on, and we released the first part of the project just before the holidays

As someone who's used Pages for coming up on 1/3 of my life, I'm _really_ happy to hear that there's work being done on this <3

> At a high level, what this changes is the built content gets stored in Actions artifacts instead of a special branch/folder of the repository. Setting up and enabling pages would be done by adding a workflow flow that makes use of the new deploy-pages action, or you could otherwise setup your own workflow that uses the new pages deployment API. This can be further simplified using composite actions so that anyone can create a workflow that abstracts these steps using optimized defaults for their framework of choice.

This all sounds like a pretty good direction (pending personal reservations about the challenges around Actions)!

> but we also want to treat Pages the same as any other cloud target

I really love hearing this. Specifically, I think there are other enhancements across the products that can be made to allow more tightly coupled yet agnostic integrations with cloud targets, and I'm glad to hear that how you're thinking about this doesn't preclude that.

> In general if you have a workflow like this that runs on: push to a given branch, deploying can be done with just a simple git push, then the workflow takes care of deploying your site after it's built!  gh workflow run gh-pages then just becomes a manual way to trigger that same workflow without having to do another push.

totally makes sense

> Open to suggestions and ideas around this, but I wanted to provide some context around the new flow since it's something we're actively working on so we can finally break the dependency on the special gh-pages branch.

I think you've generally covered everything I'd want to talk about. Very much looking forward to the results of the work y'all are doing <3

issue.title: Somehow support checking if a path exists while using fs.promises

labels.name: fs
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the fs subsystem / file system.

labels.name: feature request
labels.description: Issues that request new features to be added to Node.js.

issue.body:
<!--
Thank you for suggesting an idea to make Node.js better.

Please fill in as much of the template below as you're able.
-->

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Presently, `fs.exists` is deprecated and `fs.existsSync` is only available if you're not using `promises`. The exists check is absolutely useful, and it would be really useful to have it available in the `fs.promises` API.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

`fs.promises,exists` or `fs.promises.existsSync` should work.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

- Status Quo: this leaves a weird and very unfortunate gap in our API.

comment.body: @jasnell that would solve it, although it definitely feels like an API departure in a way that I'd _hope_ we'd be able to avoid.

pull_request.title: tools: do not mask errors on multiple commit retrieval

In commit-queue.sh, the assignment to `commits` will succeed and the
script will continue if one of the two `git` commands fails, even with
`-e` set. Split it into three separate assignments so that failures in
the `git` commands will be clearly logged and cause the script to exit
with a failure status code.

issue.title: Periodic Table does not have an element starting with "J" or "Q" or "W"
issue.body:
> All LTS releases will be assigned a "codename" drawn from the names of elements on the Periodic Table of Elements. For each upcoming LTS release, the Release working group will select a handful of candidate names and submit those for a collaborator vote.

I looked up the [List of chemical elements](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_chemical_elements) and noticed there are no elements starting with "J" or "Q" or "W".

I realize that we won't hit "J" for 7 more LTS releases but I'm curious...how will the "codename" be decided in those 3 cases?

------

*UPDATE*: looks like I'm not the first to [notice](https://github.com/nodejs/Release/issues/163#issuecomment-288850282) this problem.
Maybe other [languages](https://github.com/nodejs/Release/issues/163#issuecomment-288882542) could solve it.

comment.body: +1 to Jumbonium

issue.title: move bnb/devenv to nodejs/devcontainer
issue.body:
per https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/39672, it seems the next steps would be to move the [bnb/devenv](https://github.com/bnb/devenv) repository into the Node.js org and to PR the `.devcontainer` dir to nodejs/node. I'd recommend moving it to nodejs/devcontainer.

One thing to note, we'd need to grab a Docker Hub token to publish it to the Node.js Docker Hub account to publish the image. I presume we'll want to publish it to `nodejs/devcontainer` to match the repo. We _will_ need to choose some kind of name, which will need to be reflected in code [here](https://github.com/bnb/devenv/blob/main/.github/workflows/docker-build-and-publish.yml#L26).

Worth noting that this *will* consume some portion of our Actions minutes. In its first run, it took about an hour and a half to build and publish on the default 2 core runner. I've presently set it up to run nightly, though the cron can be changed through normal means in GitHub. I've talked a bit with the Actions team and it seems that we'd potentially be able to get dedicated runners for this workload - I'll follow up with them once we've moved the repo into the org  

Happy to do this but want to get the appropriate approvals, of course :)

issue.title: doc: add styleguide

labels.name: doc
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the documentations.

issue.body:
This PR adds a documentation style guide. This comes as a result of https://github.com/nodejs/node/discussions/40953 and the various next-10 discussions that led to it. It is _largely_ a copy/paste from electron/electron's [styleguide.md](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/main/docs/styleguide.md), with some changes.

The goal of this is not to have it as an immediately enforceable, but rather to have it be planted as the guide that we'll eventually fully enforce on all documentation that it can be enforced on (some documentation, like native APIs, it can only be partially enforced on).

Landing this and, eventually, having all of our documentation written in this style should allows us the ability to use [docs-parser](https://github.com/electron/docs-parser) which produces a high-quality JSON output of markdown documentation written as the style guide defines. This would allow the DefinitelyTyped people to produce higher quality type definitions, potentially even just using Electron's [typescript-definitions](https://github.com/electron/typescript-definitions) tooling that parses docs-parser output into `.d.ts` files.

There are other, less objective benefits:
- highly consistent authoring experience that provides a consistent framework for writing and reviewing documentation
- more digestible documentation for end-users, structuring all documentation in a hierarchy that's consistent across pages while still being specific enough to provide meaningful context regardless of content

Worth noting, I also created https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/32206 some time ago, and this is one step towards that as a reality. In doing so, I also created [bnb/node-docs-parser](https://github.com/bnb/node-docs-parser) which snapshotted a few examples from the Node.js documentation at the time I created it and provided an example of what those documents would look like if they were migrated. While it's been a pandemic worth of time since I last worked on that repo and some of the docs have been updated (querystring in particular is much more consistent!), the documents in `/docs/api` are still pretty close to what the "translated" versions would look like if you want a reference.

changes to the styleguide.md from the e/e version include:

- updating the name (`Electron` > `Node.js`)
- removing references to `markdownlint`
  - given that Electron and docs-parser use markdownlint, it might make sense to migrate to it.
- removed a TODO above the linter rules, noting that they should be checked against what the electron/electron markdown parser checks for.
  - potentially worth investigating finding a middle ground and both using one set of tooling.
- tweaked examples to fit Node.js. As we build out the documentation to fit this style guide, we should update these examples to me more thorough.
- removed one example under the "function signature" heading on line 169, as I'm not immediately familiar of a class that has the same name as its module and can be used as an example. Happy to re-add this when I find a good example.
  - here's the original text, for reference: 
    - > For example, the methods of the `Session` class under the `session` module must use `ses` as the `objectName`.
- removed a reference on line 181 to Electron's cookie API custom sturcutre. Happy to re-add this back in once we've got our own custom structures added.
- added backticks to line 228 where they weren't in the Electron documentation. I believe the backticks are allowed/required, but should double check just to make sure that's a correct assertion before merging.

a few things to discuss:
- js code linting
  - Electron's standardized on StandardJS and has proper tooling for it, including [standard-markdown](https://www.npmjs.com/package/standard-markdown). While I'm personally fine with this, I assume the Node.js project would want a different linter solution documented.
  - happy to change the text on lines 55-56 referencing this if we don't want to keep this.
- I'm not sure if we have platform-specific functionality. If we don't and never plan on doing so, happy to remove line 194-203.
- how we want to approach inline YAML changelogs. Particularly, it was raised that it would be nice to have in Markdown but it may also become burdensome for those who backport, which is definitely not something I'd want to see.
  - potential solution here is to document an additional markdown structure for changelogs and then have a small tool convert YAML into that Markdown structure as a build step.
  - I'm unopinionated on what a solution is here, but ideally, we will *eventually* not have any YAML frontmatter.

and just for context, the ideal next steps _after_ this PR lands would be to begin incrementally migrating documentation to fit the style guide.

comment.body: I've been told it'll be looked at. Electron is [taking December off](https://electronjs.org/blog/a-quiet-place-21), so it might not happen this month

issue.title: Create a .github repo
issue.body:
Per the GitHub Org Management Policy, I'm requesting that we create a .github repo so that we can put a SECURITY.md file there that will appear in the GitHub interface for all nodejs org repos that do not already have a SECURITY.md repo.

Ref: https://github.com/nodejs/security-wg/issues/776#issuecomment-987610423

@nodejs/tsc @nodejs/security-triage 

Policy says this is automatically approved after 72 hours if there are no TSC member objections.

Thanks.

comment.body: Yep, that is a tradeoff. The one caveat I'd present is that our _current_ CoC isn't actually a CoC: it's a link to our CoC. We've not actually got a CoC in any repo except nodejs/admin right now, and I'm not sure if the impact of the one/two links is the same as having a full CoC checked in to the source.

issue.title: Publish to nodejs/devcontainer rather than bnb/devenv
issue.body:
presently, we're publishing the docker image to bnb/devenv on Docker Hub. Ideally, we'd be able to change that to publishing to nodejs/devcontainer on Docker Hub.

We'd need to add correct secrets (cc @nodejs/docker) to this repo, which would be consumed by the build and publish action [here](https://github.com/nodejs/devcontainer/blob/main/.github/workflows/docker-build-and-publish.yml#L19-L20).

Further, we'd want to update the tags [here](https://github.com/nodejs/devcontainer/blob/main/.github/workflows/docker-build-and-publish.yml#L26) to `nodejs/devcontainer:latest`.

issue.title: Install Slack GitHub app for nodejs/node
issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

 Apologies if this isn't the best place (I thought about asking in Slack, but decided here might be better).

I would like to be able to use the Slack GitHub app to subscribe to releases from nodejs/node.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Would it be possible for someone to install https://slack.github.com/ for nodejs/node, so that folks using the GitHub app in Slack can subscribe to releases etc. there?

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

- Creating a custom webhook workflow, which requires overhead to monitor for releases there, and then fire a webhook into Slack.
- Using the default RSS Slack integration with the GitHub releases RSS feed. This works, but doesn't provide the same level of integration/formatting as using the GitHub app.

comment.body:
As a heads up, this isn't actually a "new" app. It's already installed, and the Moderation team takes advantage of it. I've found it particularly useful as a tool to be instantly notified when a new issue is created in nodejs/moderation and there have been a few occasions where it's significantly sped up my ability to respond to incidents.

I fully support this being used in the OpenJS Foundation Slack and would greatly benefit from that myself, but one thing I'm not sure about is if it can be connected to multiple Slack teams.

issue.title: Create a .github repo
issue.body:
Per the GitHub Org Management Policy, I'm requesting that we create a .github repo so that we can put a SECURITY.md file there that will appear in the GitHub interface for all nodejs org repos that do not already have a SECURITY.md repo.

Ref: https://github.com/nodejs/security-wg/issues/776#issuecomment-987610423

@nodejs/tsc @nodejs/security-triage 

Policy says this is automatically approved after 72 hours if there are no TSC member objections.

Thanks.

comment.body: yep, the files aren't templates so much as context for GitHub's UI (for example, in the sidebar of the main repo page and in issues/PRs).

issue.body:
This is a backport of https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/40280 to `v12.x-staging`. There are actually no merge conflicts and the commits cherry-pick cleanly but it was [suggested in the most recent release WG meeting](https://github.com/nodejs/Release/blob/main/doc/meetings/2021-12-02.md) to open a backport pull request to drive discussion on whether we should update the root certificates in maintenance LTS (i.e. 12.x and 14.x). Please post comments if you have views either way on whether we should update the root certificates in the maintenance LTS lines.

See the commit messages for the list of root certificates added and removed.

cc @nodejs/lts

issue.title: Create a .github repo
issue.body:
Per the GitHub Org Management Policy, I'm requesting that we create a .github repo so that we can put a SECURITY.md file there that will appear in the GitHub interface for all nodejs org repos that do not already have a SECURITY.md repo.

Ref: https://github.com/nodejs/security-wg/issues/776#issuecomment-987610423

@nodejs/tsc @nodejs/security-triage 

Policy says this is automatically approved after 72 hours if there are no TSC member objections.

Thanks.

comment.body: SGTM. Might want to consider also migrating our CoC to just live there, since most checked in CoC files already point to this repo rather than actually checking in the CoC.

issue.title: Nominating Tierney Cyren (bnb) to be a collaborator

labels.name: feature request
labels.description: Issues that request new features to be added to Node.js.

issue.body:
<!--
Thank you for suggesting an idea to make Node.js better.

Please fill in as much of the template below as you're able.
-->

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Lack of bnb in collaborator team.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

bnb in collaborator team.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

bnb in triage team.

--

I'd like to nominate Tierney Cyren (@bnb) to be a collaborator. While their code contributions to core are small thus far, their involvement in the project specifically and the community in general is significant and therefore (IMO) warrants a nomination.

Tierney is a member of the Moderation Team and was the chair of the Community Committee for (I think) the last few years. They have been involved in many `nodejs` org repositories (see first link in bulleted list that follows).

* Pull requests and issues opened throughout the Node.js organization: https://github.com/search?q=author:bnb+org:nodejs
* Commits in nodejs/node: https://github.com/nodejs/node/commits?author=bnb
* Pull requests and issues in nodejs/node: https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues?q=author:bnb
* Comments on pull requests and issues in nodejs/node: https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues?q=commenter:bnb
* Reviews on pull requests in nodejs/node: https://github.com/nodejs/node/pulls?q=reviewed-by:bnb
* Help provided to end-users and novice contributors: https://github.com/nodejs/help/issues?q=commenter:bnb

comment.body: thanks y'all

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,248 @@
+# Node.js Documentation Style Guide
+
+These are the guidelines for writing Node.js documentation.
+
+## Headings
+
+* Each page must have a single `#`-level title at the top.
+* Chapters in the same page must have `##`-level headings.
+* Sub-chapters need to increase the number of `#` in the heading according to
+  their nesting depth.
+* The page's title must follow [APA title case][title-case].
+* All chapters must follow [APA sentence case][sentence-case].
+
+Using a hypothetical `Quick Start` as an example:
+
+```markdown
+# How to write a test for the Node.js project
+
+...
+
+## What is a test?
+
+...
+
+## Test directory structure
+
+...
+
+## Test structure
+
+...
+
+### **Lines 1-3**
+
+...
+
+### **Lines 5-6**
+
+...
+```
+
+For API references, there are exceptions to this rule.
+
+## Markdown rules
+
+This repository uses the [`remark-preset-lint-node`][remark-preset-lint-node]
+package to enforce consistent Markdown styling. For the exact rules, see
+[nodejs/remark-preset-lint-node][nodejs/remark-preset-lint-node]. Additionally,
+we're beginning to use [docs-parser][docs-parser] to parse the Markdown
+into an API.
+
+There are a few style guidelines that aren't covered by the linter rules:
+
+* Use `sh` instead of `cmd` in code blocks (due to the syntax highlighter).
+* Keep line lengths between 80 and 100 characters if possible for readability
+  purposes.
+* No nesting lists more than 2 levels (due to the markdown renderer).
+* All `js` and `javascript` code blocks are linted with
+  [standard-markdown](https://www.npmjs.com/package/standard-markdown).
+* For unordered lists, use asterisks instead of dashes.
+
+## Picking words
+
+* Use "will" over "would" when describing outcomes.
+
+## API references
+
+The following rules only apply to the documentation of APIs.
+
+### Title and description
+
+Each module's API doc must use the actual object name returned by requiring it
+as its title (such as `path`, `fs`, and `querystring`).
+
+Directly under the page title, add a one-line description of the module
+as a markdown quote (beginning with `>`).
+
+Using the `session` module as an example:
comment.body:

Using the `querystring` module as an example:

pull_request.title: doc: add styleguide
pull_request.body:
This PR adds a documentation style guide. This comes as a result of https://github.com/nodejs/node/discussions/40953 and the various next-10 discussions that led to it. It is _largely_ a copy/paste from electron/electron's [styleguide.md](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/main/docs/styleguide.md), with some changes.

The goal of this is not to have it as an immediately enforceable, but rather to have it be planted as the guide that we'll eventually fully enforce on all documentation that it can be enforced on (some documentation, like native APIs, it can only be partially enforced on).

Landing this and, eventually, having all of our documentation written in this style should allows us the ability to use [docs-parser](https://github.com/electron/docs-parser) which produces a high-quality JSON output of markdown documentation written as the style guide defines. This would allow the DefinitelyTyped people to produce higher quality type definitions, potentially even just using Electron's [typescript-definitions](https://github.com/electron/typescript-definitions) tooling that parses docs-parser output into `.d.ts` files.

There are other, less objective benefits:
- highly consistent authoring experience that provides a consistent framework for writing and reviewing documentation
- more digestible documentation for end-users, structuring all documentation in a hierarchy that's consistent across pages while still being specific enough to provide meaningful context regardless of content

Worth noting, I also created https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/32206 some time ago, and this is one step towards that as a reality. In doing so, I also created [bnb/node-docs-parser](https://github.com/bnb/node-docs-parser) which snapshotted a few examples from the Node.js documentation at the time I created it and provided an example of what those documents would look like if they were migrated. While it's been a pandemic worth of time since I last worked on that repo and some of the docs have been updated (querystring in particular is much more consistent!), the documents in `/docs/api` are still pretty close to what the "translated" versions would look like if you want a reference.

changes to the styleguide.md from the e/e version include:

- updating the name (`Electron` > `Node.js`)
- removing references to `markdownlint`
  - given that Electron and docs-parser use markdownlint, it might make sense to migrate to it.
- removed a TODO above the linter rules, noting that they should be checked against what the electron/electron markdown parser checks for.
  - potentially worth investigating finding a middle ground and both using one set of tooling.
- tweaked examples to fit Node.js. As we build out the documentation to fit this style guide, we should update these examples to me more thorough.
- removed one example under the "function signature" heading on line 169, as I'm not immediately familiar of a class that has the same name as its module and can be used as an example. Happy to re-add this when I find a good example.
  - here's the original text, for reference: 
    - > For example, the methods of the `Session` class under the `session` module must use `ses` as the `objectName`.
- removed a reference on line 181 to Electron's cookie API custom sturcutre. Happy to re-add this back in once we've got our own custom structures added.
- added backticks to line 228 where they weren't in the Electron documentation. I believe the backticks are allowed/required, but should double check just to make sure that's a correct assertion before merging.

a few things to discuss:
- js code linting
  - Electron's standardized on StandardJS and has proper tooling for it, including [standard-markdown](https://www.npmjs.com/package/standard-markdown). While I'm personally fine with this, I assume the Node.js project would want a different linter solution documented.
  - happy to change the text on lines 55-56 referencing this if we don't want to keep this.
- I'm not sure if we have platform-specific functionality. If we don't and never plan on doing so, happy to remove line 194-203.
- how we want to approach inline YAML changelogs. Particularly, it was raised that it would be nice to have in Markdown but it may also become burdensome for those who backport, which is definitely not something I'd want to see.
  - potential solution here is to document an additional markdown structure for changelogs and then have a small tool convert YAML into that Markdown structure as a build step.
  - I'm unopinionated on what a solution is here, but ideally, we will *eventually* not have any YAML frontmatter.

and just for context, the ideal next steps _after_ this PR lands would be to begin incrementally migrating documentation to fit the style guide.

labels.name: doc
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the documentations.

pull_request.title: doc: add styleguide
pull_request.body:
This PR adds a documentation style guide. This comes as a result of https://github.com/nodejs/node/discussions/40953 and the various next-10 discussions that led to it. It is _largely_ a copy/paste from electron/electron's [styleguide.md](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/main/docs/styleguide.md), with some changes.

The goal of this is not to have it as an immediately enforceable, but rather to have it be planted as the guide that we'll eventually fully enforce on all documentation that it can be enforced on (some documentation, like native APIs, it can only be partially enforced on).

Landing this and, eventually, having all of our documentation written in this style should allows us the ability to use [docs-parser](https://github.com/electron/docs-parser) which produces a high-quality JSON output of markdown documentation written as the style guide defines. This would allow the DefinitelyTyped people to produce higher quality type definitions, potentially even just using Electron's [typescript-definitions](https://github.com/electron/typescript-definitions) tooling that parses docs-parser output into `.d.ts` files.

There are other, less objective benefits:
- highly consistent authoring experience that provides a consistent framework for writing and reviewing documentation
- more digestible documentation for end-users, structuring all documentation in a hierarchy that's consistent across pages while still being specific enough to provide meaningful context regardless of content

Worth noting, I also created https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/32206 some time ago, and this is one step towards that as a reality. In doing so, I also created [bnb/node-docs-parser](https://github.com/bnb/node-docs-parser) which snapshotted a few examples from the Node.js documentation at the time I created it and provided an example of what those documents would look like if they were migrated. While it's been a pandemic worth of time since I last worked on that repo and some of the docs have been updated (querystring in particular is much more consistent!), the documents in `/docs/api` are still pretty close to what the "translated" versions would look like if you want a reference.

changes to the styleguide.md from the e/e version include:

- updating the name (`Electron` > `Node.js`)
- removing references to `markdownlint`
  - given that Electron and docs-parser use markdownlint, it might make sense to migrate to it.
- removed a TODO above the linter rules, noting that they should be checked against what the electron/electron markdown parser checks for.
  - potentially worth investigating finding a middle ground and both using one set of tooling.
- tweaked examples to fit Node.js. As we build out the documentation to fit this style guide, we should update these examples to me more thorough.
- removed one example under the "function signature" heading on line 169, as I'm not immediately familiar of a class that has the same name as its module and can be used as an example. Happy to re-add this when I find a good example.
  - here's the original text, for reference: 
    - > For example, the methods of the `Session` class under the `session` module must use `ses` as the `objectName`.
- removed a reference on line 181 to Electron's cookie API custom sturcutre. Happy to re-add this back in once we've got our own custom structures added.
- added backticks to line 228 where they weren't in the Electron documentation. I believe the backticks are allowed/required, but should double check just to make sure that's a correct assertion before merging.

a few things to discuss:
- js code linting
  - Electron's standardized on StandardJS and has proper tooling for it, including [standard-markdown](https://www.npmjs.com/package/standard-markdown). While I'm personally fine with this, I assume the Node.js project would want a different linter solution documented.
  - happy to change the text on lines 55-56 referencing this if we don't want to keep this.
- I'm not sure if we have platform-specific functionality. If we don't and never plan on doing so, happy to remove line 194-203.
- how we want to approach inline YAML changelogs. Particularly, it was raised that it would be nice to have in Markdown but it may also become burdensome for those who backport, which is definitely not something I'd want to see.
  - potential solution here is to document an additional markdown structure for changelogs and then have a small tool convert YAML into that Markdown structure as a build step.
  - I'm unopinionated on what a solution is here, but ideally, we will *eventually* not have any YAML frontmatter.

and just for context, the ideal next steps _after_ this PR lands would be to begin incrementally migrating documentation to fit the style guide.
